verses.text: Wisdom will praise herself, and in the midst of her people she will be honored.
verses.comment: Wisdom personified here echoes Lady Wisdom in Proverbs, both revealing her glory among God's chosen people.

verses.text: In the assembly of the Most High, she will open her mouth, and in the presence of his host she will be glorified:
verses.comment: Wisdom’s proclamation in the divine council suggests her authority and presence before God’s angels.

verses.text: ‘I came forth from the mouth of the Most High, and covered the earth like a mist.
verses.comment: This speaks to Wisdom’s divine origin, prefiguring the Word’s coming forth (John 1:1).

verses.text: I dwelt in high places, and my throne was in a pillar of cloud.
verses.comment: Wisdom resided with God, reminiscent of God’s presence in the cloud in Exodus.

verses.text: Alone, I have encircled the vault of heaven, and walked in the depths of the abyss.
verses.comment: Wisdom’s universal presence and power mirror God’s creative activity.

verses.text: Over waves of the sea, and all of the earth, and over every people and nation, I have held sway.
verses.comment: Wisdom’s dominion is universal, reflecting God’s sovereignty over all creation.

verses.text: Among all these, I sought a resting place, in whose inheritance should I lodge?
verses.comment: Wisdom seeks a home, revealing the intimacy God desires with His people.

verses.text: So then the Creator of all commanded me, and he who created me assigned my dwelling, and said, ‘Pitch your tent in Jacob, and in Israel receive your inheritance.’
verses.comment: Wisdom is sent to dwell in Israel, alluding to God’s special dwelling among His people. The language echoes the Incarnation.

verses.text: Before all ages, in the beginning, he created me, and for all eternity I shall not cease to exist.
verses.comment: Refers to Wisdom’s eternal existence, paralleling descriptions of the Logos, or Word, in John’s Gospel.

verses.text: I ministered in the holy tent before him, and so I was established in Zion.
verses.comment: Wisdom’s placement in Zion, the location of the Temple, highlights God’s manifestation in worship.

verses.text: In the beloved city he gave me rest, and in Jerusalem was my authority.
verses.comment: Wisdom is identified with Jerusalem, the holy city, symbolizing God's chosen dwelling.

verses.text: I grew tall like a cedar in Lebanon and like a cypress in the mountains of Hermon.
verses.comment: Wisdom’s imagery as trees evokes growth, strength, and permanence, commonly associated with righteousness.

verses.text: I grew tall like a palm tree in Engedi, and like rose bushes in Jericho; like a beautiful olive tree in the field, and like a plane tree, I grew tall.
verses.comment: These botanical images point to fruitfulness and attractiveness, spiritual blessings arising from Wisdom.

verses.text: I gave off fragrance like cinnamon and acanthus, and I yielded a sweet scent like precious myrrh.
verses.comment: Wisdom’s presence is pleasing, reminiscent of offerings in the sanctuary and the Bridal imagery of Song of Solomon.

verses.text: I spread out my branches like a terebinth, and my branches were branches of glory and grace.
verses.comment: The image of spreading branches alludes to messianic promises and blessings to the nations.

verses.text: I was like a vine, producing beautiful shoots, and my blossoms bore rich fruit:
verses.comment: Imagery of the vine recalls both Israel and Christ as the true vine (John 15).

verses.text: Pride is in the buds and glory in the fruit. My roots are firm in honored people and my inheritance is found in the portion of the Lord.
verses.comment: Wisdom’s fruit flourishes among those who honor the Lord, a principle seen throughout Scripture.

verses.text: I was stretched out like a vine, making splendor, and my blossoms became the fruit of glory and riches.
verses.comment: Spiritual prosperity is depicted as the result of Wisdom’s work.

verses.text: Come to me, you who desire me, and be filled with my fruits.
verses.comment: Wisdom’s invitation mirrors Christ’s call to ‘Come to me’ (Matt. 11:28), offering spiritual nourishment.

verses.text: For remembering me is sweeter than honey, and inheriting me is sweeter than the honeycomb.
verses.comment: Knowing Wisdom brings true sweetness, recalling the delight found in God’s word.

verses.text: Those who eat me will hunger for more, and those who drink me will thirst for more.
verses.comment: This verse has Eucharistic overtones, prefiguring Christ’s offering of Himself as the Bread of Life.

verses.text: Whoever obeys me will never be put to shame, and those who work with me will not sin.
verses.comment: Living in Wisdom’s ways keeps one from shame and sin, reflecting the call to holiness through obedience.

verses.text: All this is the book of the covenant of the Most High God, the law which Moses commanded us as an inheritance for the assemblies of Jacob.
verses.comment: Identification of Wisdom with the Law parallels claims in the New Testament that Christ fulfills the Law.

verses.text: Do not neglect to be strong in the Lord, but persevere so that he may strengthen you; the Lord Almighty himself is God, and besides him there is no other savior.
verses.comment: Encourages faithfulness to God alone as Savior, a theme foundational to biblical monotheism.

verses.text: He fills wisdom’s storehouses with knowledge, and he poured out wisdom’s understanding like the river Pishon, like the Tigris in the days of new fruit.
verses.comment: God’s abundance in wisdom and knowledge is compared to the rivers of Eden, symbolizing life and blessing.

verses.text: He makes understanding pour forth like the Euphrates, and multiplies it like the Jordan in harvest time;
verses.comment: Wisdom’s spreading, again linked to sources of life and abundance, suggesting the unstoppable flow of divine insight.

verses.text: He makes knowledge shine like light and raises her up like the Gihon in the days of vintage.
verses.comment: Enlightening imagery, tying knowledge and wisdom to the rivers watering Eden’s garden, symbols for grace.

verses.text: The first man never fully comprehended wisdom, nor has the last fully explored her;
verses.comment: No human reaches the depths of divine wisdom, underscoring its transcendent nature.

verses.text: For her thoughts are broader than the sea, and her plans are deeper than the great abyss.
verses.comment: A poetic reminder that divine understanding is infinite, creating humility before God.

verses.text: Now I myself went forth like a canal from a river, and like a watercourse into a garden.
verses.comment: Wisdom’s flow nourishes a garden—an Eden motif for abundant spiritual life.

verses.text: I said, ‘I will make my garden irrigated, and I will water my flower beds abundantly.’ And behold, my canal became a river, and my river a sea.
verses.comment: The increase from a channel to a sea shows the exponential growth of wisdom when received and shared.

verses.text: I will make instruction shine like the dawn, and I will announce it far away.
verses.comment: Wisdom is not hidden but revealed to all who seek, just as Christ proclaims the light of truth to the nations.

verses.text: I will pour out teaching like prophecy, and leave it for generations to come.
verses.comment: Wisdom’s teaching is meant for every generation, reflecting the importance of sacred tradition transmitted in the community.

verses.text: See, I have not labored for myself alone, but for all who seek wisdom.
verses.comment: Wisdom works for the benefit of all, inviting all who earnestly seek her. This universal invitation subtly points toward the unity of faith for all peoples.
